channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Ireland’s Economy Surges as U.S. Businesses Stockpile Ahead of Possible Tariffs
item.description: The economy surged as U.S. pharmaceutical giants based in the country boosted production to build stockpiles back home ahead of threatened tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Eurozone Business Sentiment Takes Hit From Tariffs
item.description: The services, industrial and construction sectors all saw worsening sentiment compared with March, as did consumer confidence.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Tariffs to Weaken Growth and Inflation, ECB’s Cipollone Says
item.description: Closer cooperation between countries that favor trade openness is needed to avoid worse outcomes for the global economy according to the senior official at the European Central Bank.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Spanish Economy Keeps Growing But Tariffs Set to Drag Momentum
item.description: The growth is a sign of continued underlying strength in the wealthy world’s top-performing economy, though trade tariffs could yet act as a brake.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: German Consumers Shrug Off Tariff Concerns as Confidence Unexpectedly Picks Up
item.description: Trump’s tariff flurry hasn’t yet had a lasting impact on consumer sentiment, said Rolf Buerkl, consumer expert at NIM.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: China Offers Olive Branch to U.S. Firms After Boeing Delivery Halt
item.description: Beijing is willing to support normal business cooperation with American firms, China’s commerce ministry said, coming days after Chinese airlines were ordered to stop taking delivery of Boeing aircraft.

item.title: Heard on the Street: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all
item.description: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos

item.title: U.S. fabric makers that stand to win more business because of tariffs are navigating uncertainty in trade policy and consumer demand
item.description: Fabric makers that stand to win more business because of tariffs are navigating uncertainty in trade policy and consumer demand.
item.dc:creator: Liz Young

item.title: ECB Has Room to Lower Key Rate as Inflation Nears Target, Says Villeroy
item.description: The head of the Bank of France also said that while slower economic growth in the U.S. would be a blow, it presented Europe with an opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Bank of Japan Likely to Hold Rates Amid Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: The Bank of Japan is widely expected to maintain its policy rate unchanged at 0.5% at a two-day meeting ending Thursday as it waits to see if Japan will be exempt from President Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: State and local governments rolled out the red carpet to federal workers who were laid off en masse this year, but many federal applicants are still waiting to get through the door
item.description: Soaring demand, red tape, and mismatched opportunities are frustrating some new job seekers.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: China has exempted some U.S. imports that the country would struggle to immediately source from elsewhere from its retaliatory tariffs, people familiar with the matter said
item.description: Beijing has been canvassing companies and waiving duties on American goods in sectors where it lacks alternatives.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Cheng

item.title: Americans are feeling gloomy about the economy after President Trump’s market-rattling first few months in office. But overall they are keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.description: People are still buying things at a steady clip, keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: American households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment
item.description: Households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: U.K. Consumers’ Mood Darkens Under Tariff Clouds
item.description: Consumers in the U.K. are growing more pessimistic as they fear the weight of trade tariffs and renewed high inflation, according to research group GfK.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: President Trump backed off an implied threat to fire Fed Chair Jerome Powell. But the president’s conduct could undermine investors’ confidence in whomever he picks as the next Fed chair.
item.description: The president’s attacks on Jerome Powell could put a “shadow of suspicion” over whomever Trump picks as the next central-bank chief.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Sales of existing homes in March posted their biggest monthly decline in more than two years
item.description: Many buyers, spooked by rising economic uncertainty, stayed away from the housing market during the start of the crucial spring season.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: U.K. Risks Higher Inflation if It Retaliates Against Tariffs, BOE’s Bailey Warns
item.description: The U.K. has been hopeful of a trade deal with the U.S., but had previously drawn up a list of items for potential retaliation after Trump’s April 2 announcement.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: The ECB should keep lowering interest rates at its next meeting in June if forecasts show eurozone inflation falling below the bank’s 2% target, governing-council member Olli Rehn said
item.description: At 2.4%, eurozone inflation is above the central bank’s 2% target, but is expected to ease over the coming months.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Rise Slightly
item.description: In the week through April 19 there were 222,000 initial jobless claims, compared with 216,000 a week earlier. Economists had been forecasting 220,000 initial claims.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Florida is the latest in a string of states to revamp or try to change child-labor laws in recent years
item.description: Florida, like some other states, is pushing softer child-labor laws to help businesses struggling to fill jobs and shifts.
item.dc:creator: Tali Arbel

item.title: German Business Sentiment Inches Higher Despite Tariff Turbulence
item.description: Sentiment unexpectedly edged up in April, likely an endorsement of policies to boost spending on defense and investments, despite the market turmoil prompted by Trump’s tariff barriers on Europe.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Trump Tariffs Show Mixed Impact on Big Economies
item.description: Business activity in the U.S. and Europe weakened in April, in contrast to pickups in Japan and India, underlining the diverse ways in which higher U.S. tariffs are affecting economies around the world.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: IMF Warns Against Support for Tariff-Hit Businesses as Government Debts Surge
item.description: Higher tariffs and heightened geopolitical tensions may push government debts to new highs over the coming years, making the need for policymakers to outline robust plans for containing the surge more pressing, the International Monetary Fund said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Indonesia’s Central Bank Holds Amid Rupiah Wobbles, Tariff Concerns
item.description: Bank Indonesia’s decision to keep its benchmark seven-day reverse repo rate at 5.75% was widely expected.
item.dc:creator: Ying Xian Wong

item.title: Their job is to calculate tariffs on every import. They had to go through “pure hell” to land it.
item.description: Almost everyone fails the open-book exam, which covers the technicalities of classifying merchandise and entry and valuation procedures; ‘pure hell’
item.dc:creator: Esther Fung

item.title: The largest credit card companies are preparing for the economy to get worse.
item.description: Already, delinquencies are rising and are now in line with levels from before the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Imani Moise

item.title: The sharp rise in tariffs marks the onset of a new era that will see most economies grow more slowly than previously expected, the IMF says
item.description: The U.S. will suffer one of the largest hits to its growth prospects in a new era that will see most economies grow more slowly than previously expected, the fund said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: The U.S. imposed steep tariffs on solar imports from four Southeast Asian countries where Chinese manufacturers have set up factories in recent years
item.description: The U.S. broadened its trade dispute with China by imposing steep tariffs on solar imports from four Southeast Asian countries where Chinese manufacturers have set up factories in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Kimberley Kao

item.title: Financial markets have flashed an ominous message this month about President Trump’s ambitious and improvisational bid to reshape global trade: Be careful what you wish for
item.description: Rising volatility and dollar weakness raise fears of a financial realignment, away from U.S. shores
item.dc:creator: Chelsey Dulaney

item.title: President Trump’s federal government shake-up is taking a toll on Washington, D.C.’s economy
item.description: The president ‘s federal government shake-up is taking a toll on the U.S. capital’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: Housing starts, a measure of home construction, dropped 11.4% in March from February, marking the steepest plunge in a year
item.description: Economic uncertainty and rising material costs from tariffs darken the outlook for newly built homes.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: The overbuilding of apartments suddenly looks like a lucky break for the multifamily industry—thanks to tariffs
item.description: The multifamily industry built more than one million new units, but now it can pause most construction ahead of potential tariffs on building materials.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Canadian Property Market Hurt by Tariff Concerns
item.description: The nascent recovery in Canada’s housing market has become a casualty of the trade dispute with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: A WSJ podcast series explores the current state of the housing market and the factors influencing the spring home buying season—and beyond
item.description: A podcast series that explores the current state of the housing market that has left many would-be buyers on the sidelines and the factors influencing the spring home buying season—and beyond.

item.title: Initial U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The week through March 29 brought 219,000 initial jobless claims, compared with 225,000 a week earlier and economists expectations of 228,000 claims.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman
